Introduction

Gastric cancers are a heterogeneous group of malignant tumors arising within the stomach; approximately 90% are adenocarcinomas.  This article focuses on gastric adenocarcinoma (both the intestinal and diffuse types), including its pathogenesis, risk factors, clinical presentation, and management.  Other less common malignancies—including gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), gastric lymphomas, and gastric neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumors—are briefly discussed.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The 2 major histologic variants of gastric cancer are intestinal-type adenocarcinoma (most common) and diffuse-type adenocarcinoma.

Intestinal-type adenocarcinoma



Intestinal-type adenocarcinoma tends to grow as a nodular, polypoid, and well-demarcated mass that protrudes into the gastric lumen; these lesions often ulcerate or bleed and must be differentiated from peptic gastric ulcers by biopsy.  Histologically, these malignancies resemble colon adenocarcinoma, with well-formed glandular structures composed of cuboidal or columnar cells (

image 1
).



Helicobacter pylori infection is a leading risk factor for intestinal-type adenocarcinoma because it causes chronic gastritis.  If untreated, it can lead to a cascade of gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and, eventually, invasive malignancy.  Other causes of chronic gastritis include pernicious anemia (ie, autoimmune gastritis) and a high-salt diet.  In addition, a high intake of nitroso-containing foods (eg, smoked meats, fermented vegetables) can damage the gastric mucosa and potentiate the effects of carcinogens.  These diets are most common in Eastern Asia (eg, China, South Korea), Eastern Europe, and the Andean portion of South America.

Diffuse-type adenocarcinoma



Diffuse-type adenocarcinoma grows in an infiltrative pattern, spreading throughout the stomach wall without forming a discrete mass.  This growth leads to a plaque-like appearance and extensive thickening of the stomach wall resembling a leather bottle (ie, linitis plastica).  Unlike intestinal-type adenocarcinoma, these tumors lack glandular structures and often consist of signet ring cells, characterized by abundant mucin droplets that push the nucleus to the periphery (

image 2
).



The primary driver of diffuse-type adenocarcinoma is the loss of the cell adhesion protein E-cadherin, often due to CDH1 mutations.  Although there is some overlap in risk factors with intestinal-type adenocarcinoma, this type is less strongly associated with environmental factors (eg, H pylori, dietary habits).

Clinical presentation

Symptoms



Many patients with gastric adenocarcinoma remain asymptomatic in early disease, leading to a delayed diagnosis.  As tumors grow, they can cause:



  • Epigastric pain, becoming more severe and constant over time.
  • Weight loss and early satiety, reflecting diminished oral intake.
  • Nausea, vomiting, and sometimes dysphagia if the tumor is in the proximal stomach.
  • Iron deficiency (microcytic) anemia due to blood oozing from friable tumor vessels; most patients lack overt signs of gastrointestinal bleeding ("slow bleed"), which can be identified on fecal occult blood testing.

Paraneoplastic manifestations



Paraneoplastic manifestations, typically seen in advanced disease, include the following:



  • Acanthosis nigricans (dark, velvety thickened plaques in flexural regions [eg, axillae, back of the neck]) (
    image 3
    ).
  • Diffuse seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trélat sign) (
    image 4
    ).
  • Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome).


The dermatologic paraneoplastic manifestations may be related to the increased levels of transforming growth factor-beta produced by tumor cells.

Metastatic manifestations



Manifestations of metastasis include:



  • Left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy (Virchow node), indicating metastatic spread through the thoracic duct.
  • Subcutaneous periumbilical nodule (Sister Mary Joseph nodule).
  • Palpable mass in the rectouterine pouch (Blumer shelf).


Bilateral ovarian metastasis (Krukenberg tumor) can be seen in some cases of diffuse-type adenocarcinoma.

Diagnosis and staging



When there is suspicion of gastric adenocarcinoma—especially in patients from high-incidence regions or those with risk factors such as chronic H pylori infection, diets rich in salt-preserved or nitroso-containing foods, smoking, or autoimmune atrophic gastritis—upper endoscopy should be performed to provide direct visualization and permit biopsy collection.  Histopathology distinguishes between intestinal- and diffuse-type adenocarcinomas and rules out other less common gastric malignancies (discussed later).



Following the initial diagnosis, staging should be performed using a CT scan of the abdomen, pelvis, and chest to detect metastatic lesions.  If metastatic disease is detected, stage IV disease can be diagnosed without further evaluation.  If CT findings are normal or equivocal, additional, more sensitive staging studies are warranted; these may include endoscopic ultrasonography, integrated positron emission tomography/CT scan (PET/CT scan), and diagnostic laparoscopy (

figure 1
).

Management



Therapeutic approaches differ depending on tumor stage, patient performance status, and tumor subtype.

Localized disease



Localized disease (ie, confined to the stomach) is treated with tumor resection.  This can be achieved through surgical gastrectomy or, in cases of multiple tumors, endoscopic resection.

Locally advanced disease



Locally advanced disease (ie, with regional node involvement) may still be amenable to resection.  However, patients are typically treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy or chemoradiotherapy before surgery to improve the chances of successful resection.  Adjuvant therapy (postoperative chemotherapy ± radiotherapy) is administered to reduce the risk of recurrence.

Metastatic disease



Metastatic disease (ie, stage IV) is managed with palliative chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy to alleviate symptoms and prolong survival.  Potentially emerging strategies also include targeted therapies (eg, trastuzumab for HER2-positive tumors) and immunotherapy (eg, checkpoint inhibitors).

Prognosis and screening



The prognosis depends heavily on the stage at diagnosis.  Early detection dramatically improves survival, but nearly 90% of patients have advanced disease at presentation.  Population-based screening programs (eg, endoscopic screening) exist in some high-incidence regions (eg, East Asia), which have led to earlier detection and better outcomes.  Elsewhere, screening is not routinely performed in the general population but may be considered for high-risk groups (eg, strong family history of gastric adenocarcinoma, CDH1 mutation carriers).  H pylori eradication is a key preventive strategy, reducing the risk of progression from chronic gastritis to malignancy.

Other gastric cancers

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors



GISTs are mesenchymal tumors most commonly arising in the stomach of older adults (usually age >65), although they can develop anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract.  These tumors are derived from interstitial cells of Cajal, which are pacemaker cells that regulate gastrointestinal smooth muscle contraction.  Although GISTs are often asymptomatic, they can present with manifestations such as abdominal pain, early satiety, gastrointestinal bleeding, and iron-deficiency anemia.



Most GISTs have mutations in KIT (or less commonly PDGFRA), protooncogenes encoding tyrosine kinase receptors involved in cellular proliferation.  As a result, the receptors are constitutively activated (ie, active regardless of ligand binding), leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, prolonged cell survival, and tumorigenesis.  Histologically, GISTs are composed of bland spindle cells arranged in fascicles or whorls (ie, spindle cell type).  They less frequently consist of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (ie, epithelioid type) or are a combination of these patterns.  The tumor cells are almost always positive for the immunohistochemical marker KIT (CD117) (

image 5
).  Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment; in unresectable or metastatic cases, tyrosine kinase inhibitors (eg, imatinib) may be effective.

Gastric lymphoma



Gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, also known as gastric marginal zone lymphoma, is a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that arises from post–germinal center memory B cells.  These cells typically express B-cell markers (eg, CD19, CD20) and mature B-cell markers (eg, CD22).  Chronic H pylori infection is detected in approximately 90% of patients, in whom it triggers chronic gastritis and leads to the recruitment and proliferation of antigen-specific T and B lymphocytes and the formation of lymphoid follicles.  Over time, this can lead to the emergence of a monoclonal B-cell line that eventually accumulates genetic abnormalities, allowing it to proliferate independently of H pylori antigens.  Histologically, these tumors are composed of small neoplastic lymphocytes that infiltrate the lamina propria, often surrounding and infiltrating gastric glands (

image 6
).



In early-stage disease, H pylori eradication (antibiotic therapy plus a proton pump inhibitor) can achieve complete remission in up to 80% of patients by eliminating the bacterial antigens driving tumor growth.  A test of cure is recommended 4 weeks after treatment to confirm eradication.  Active surveillance may be appropriate after successful infection eradication.  For patients with more advanced MALT lymphoma or in cases where H pylori is not detected, additional treatments may include radiation therapy, immunotherapy (eg, rituximab), or single-agent chemotherapy.

Gastric neuroendocrine tumors



Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), also known as carcinoid tumors, arise within enterochromaffin-like cells of the stomach and are frequently associated with hypergastrinemic states (eg, pernicious anemia, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).  Most patients with gastric NETs are asymptomatic or present with nonspecific abdominal discomfort.  However, some may experience gastrointestinal bleeding or, in cases of functionally active tumors, carcinoid syndrome (usually with atypical flushing without diarrhea due to histamine and tachykinin production instead of serotonin).



Histologically, gastric NETs exhibit nests or trabeculae of neuroendocrine cells that typically express chromogranin A and synaptophysin (

image 7
).  Smaller, localized lesions may be amenable to endoscopic or surgical resection, whereas more advanced disease can require somatostatin analogue therapy (eg, octreotide), chemotherapy, or other specialized treatments.  Other NETs are discussed in further detail in other articles.

Summary



Most gastric cancers are adenocarcinomas that can be categorized into intestinal or diffuse subtypes.  Intestinal-type adenocarcinoma is strongly linked to chronic gastritis (often due to Helicobacter pylori) and dietary factors (eg, high salt, nitroso-containing foods).  Diffuse-type adenocarcinoma is driven primarily by E-cadherin loss, typically infiltrates the stomach wall (linitis plastica), and features signet ring cells.  Patients often remain asymptomatic until later stages, when they may develop epigastric pain, weight loss, anemia, and paraneoplastic manifestations (eg, acanthosis nigricans).  Diagnosis relies on endoscopic evaluation with biopsy and staging imaging to assess disease extent.  Treatment ranges from surgical resection (for localized disease) with possible neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy to palliative chemotherapy/radiotherapy for metastatic cases.  Less common gastric cancers include gastrointestinal stromal tumors, gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphomas, and gastric neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumors.
